Fields.DialogueText: Got any pins, Captain?
Third drawer down on the right.
Thanks! Should only need... well, shoot. Looks like all of them.

Fields.MenuText: All of them? What could you possibly need this many for?
I didn't invite you into my quarters to steal my office supplies, you know.
In that case, might I suggest shell casings?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I guess I don't need ‘em all right now. But it's fun to think about.
It's not stealing if I ask first!
Hey, that's a keen idea! Got plenty of those lying around.
The thing is, I sent away for this world map the other day. Finally got here with this morning's mail, and now I need to mark it up with where I've been.
And where you want to go, I take it.
Read my mind, Cap!
We'll have to see what Command says about that.
They've never seen ships that can request their own deployments! Those Morganas in the Pacific won't know what hit them.
One step at a time, Lexington. Let's clear out these waters before we start planning our vacations.
This is a vacation! "A ship in harbor is safe, but that's not what ships are for!"
Who said that?
Someone who really gets me. Morganas ahoy!
@BATTLE
Captain? Over here!
Hello, Lexington. What's the word?
The word is "nose." Tell me what you smell, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: The salt? Par for the course at sea.
Gunsmoke. How's the target practice going?
New soap? It's nice.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, that's always there! Think about it a little harder, it'll come to you.
Keen! But that's not what I was talking about. Take another whiff.
Aww, that's sweet of you... but guess again!
Now that you mention it... is someone cooking something?
Right on the money! I told the cooks to take the afternoon off.
Smells great! What's for dinner?
Little bit of everything, Cap. New Orleans sent me some recipes and I just couldn't decide. So I turned the galley into a three-star restaurant!
That's remarkable! I didn't know you could cook.
Neither did I, but it's just following directions. How hard could it be?
... You said you told the cooks to take time off?
Sure enough!
Then who's keeping an eye on the galley?
You're lookin' at her!
And yet here you are.
Part of the ship, part of me. I can sense if any of it's burning. Isn't that neat?
I tentatively agree. Don't let the Morgana distract you, though, or we're out of a dinner.
The bigger the prize, the harder I fight!
@BATTLE
Hello, Lexington, how are - what's that on your shirt?
Oil! Nothing beats the smell of it after a hard day's repair work.
The crew must appreciate your helping them out.
Not just the crew, Captain. The Vought Corsairs have the best stories if you ask the right questions.
You can talk to the bombers?
Uh-huh! I translate for the maintenance crews. Helps them know where to fix ‘em up! If you could hear what the planes say, though... it'd make you want to get close to the action!

Fields.MenuText: I'm satisfied with being on the bridge, thanks.
Do they... you know... talk the way we do?
What do they think of all this? The war, the Morganas...?

Fields.DialogueText: Suit yourself, Captain, but it gets me thinking about the battlecruiser I almost was...
Not in a way you humans would understand. They talk more in... feelings? Sensations? Maybe if you could understand cats purring, it'd be like that.
You know, I don't think they do. They do their thing and they just want us to help them do it better.
I'm impressed, Lexington. It pays to know how all your systems work.
It comes naturally to us Belles! Ever wonder what you could do if you could talk to your hands?
Well, it's a little like that.
If you say so.
@BATTLE
Action stations, Lexington! They're coming at us from -
Eep!
Did I interrupt something?
No! Nope! Nothing going on in here, that's for sure! Let's get to the bridge, Captain!
... Roger that.
@BATTLE
Whew! What a prizefight that was! Those Morganas can really pack a punch.
Well, I'm off to report it to Command. Got some writing of your own to do, don't you?
... Yeah, you caught me.

Fields.MenuText: What's Isaac Davis cooking up lately?
Don't worry, Lexington. Your secret's safe with me.
There's no need to hide who you are, you know. You're a great writer.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Funny you should put it that way, Captain...
Thanks a mint, Captain. I know I shouldn't be this nervous...
Captain Isaac Davis is a great writer.
I'm just still getting used to sharing this with someone else.
Stage fright?
You could say that. Everyone liked the Isaac Davis story, but that's all they know about him. Wouldn't they think differently about it if they knew it was me?
They might like it better.
... Maybe you're right. I'll think about it, okay?
All right, Captain - take a look at this!
Is this what you were writing the other day?
Yep! A lot of research went into this one. It's even got my name on it!
You're that confident? This ought to be good!
Well? Whaddaya think?
"Lady Lex's Finger-Lickin' Galley Guide?"
Isn't it catchy?
Lexington, this is... a cookbook?
I took lots of notes when I cooked for the crew that one time. Just wait until they get a taste of my stuff on the mainland!

Fields.MenuText: It all looks tasty, but it wasn't what I had in mind when I suggested you put your name to your work.
That was a great dinner. Are all Belles this good at cooking?
Oof. It's heavy.

Fields.DialogueText: I wouldn't have signed it if I weren't proud of it. And we know everyone likes my cooking!
At least when it comes to our home countries' food. I tried doing paella one time, and the less said about that, the better!
I'm not ashamed to admit that half of it is deep-fried!
Got a publisher?
Not yet, but the hard part is picking one. They're falling all over themselves to get at a Belle book!
Definitely a good place to start. Reputation is everything.
I guess that explains why this Morgana's trying to sneak up on us. We'll show her sneaky!
Letter for you, Lexington.
About time! It feels like forever since I wrote to Saratoga...
I thought you two didn't get along.
Oh, no, we're chums through and through! We might not see eye to eye all the time, but who says sisters have to? Let's see... oh. Well, I guess that's not a surprise.
Something wrong?
Nah, not really. Saratoga says Aunt Langley still isn't feeling well.
Aunt Langley?
... Heh. I'll fill you in after this Morgana gets off our backs.
@BATTLE
So, tell me about Aunt Langley.
You already know of her, Captain. I wasn't the first first aircraft carrier, after all...
You mean the USS Langley. Isn't she a seaplane tender now? She isn't a Belle.
You're right. She hasn't awakened yet.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean "yet?" You think she will?
You and Saratoga are more than a handful for the Morganas. I wouldn't worry.
That must be frustrating.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't see why not, Captain. Turkey's got Yavuz - she's older than Aunt Langley, and she's been around since the Morganas appeared.
I know that, but... well, Saratoga and I wouldn't be who we are without her. Plus, I'm sure her insight would be invaluable, even now.
We know she's somewhere in there, but not even Belles know how to wake each other up.
It sounds like you really look up to her.
Uh-huh! We faced off in Fleet Problem X, and a lot of her pilots ended up serving on Saratoga and me. She taught us a lot. I figure the least we can do is say thank you... when we can.
In a way you both are. You're out here risking your lives every day to protect her.
Thanks, Cap, I appreciate it. Still, just imagine...
All right, everyone stay vigilant! There's still a lot we don't know about the Morganas, but we'll learn... and then they'll learn a thing or two from us.
"... a thing or two from us."
You don't have to take notes, Lexington. I'm just trying to keep the crew's spirits up.
Nah, this isn't for studying or anything. You just never know what would sound cool in an adventure story!
@BATTLE
Did I hear you say you were writing again?
Trying to! You never know when inspiration will strike.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we should hold another contest. That ought to light a fire under you to finish something.
Can you tell me what you're planning, or is that a secret?
Just like with the Morganas, you have to be ready for anything.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll have to see what Captain Isaac thinks about that, Cap, but something tells me he'd be delighted!
And give away the ending? No, sir! You get to read it when it's done and no earlier!
Yep! And just like with the Morganas, the good guys always win in my stories!
Good to know. I'm looking forward to it!
You'd better!
*ALARM*
I'm here! We finally spotted her?
We finally did.
I know there's something wrong with calling a battle to the death a relief, but...
I know exactly how you feel.
@BATTLE
Woo-hoo!
I agree. That Morgana had been menacing our merchant shipping for weeks.
That too, Captain, but did you see the mail today?
I must have missed it. Get something nice?
More like somethings! They want to translate my cookbook into all the Allied languages!
Congratulations! When is the release?
That's the catch..."when things die down" was the response I got. Could be any time, couldn't it?
Sounds to me like an incentive to finish this war faster.
Yep! Man, we should start timing our fights...
Let's not turn this into a competition.
Just spitballing, Captain!
Hey, Captain! What brings you to the radio room?
Just making the rounds. Does insulting the Morganas really throw them off, or is it just a morale booster?
Whatever it does, the crew's sure having fun with it! Hey, Morganas, you lowlifes couldn't hit water in the ocean!
Perhaps because your hull takes up too much space...
Whoa! That was a good one.
Who was that? I don't recognize that voice.
Sounded like Mischief. I think she likes trying out different voices, just to cause trouble.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we'll just have to talk back.
The Morganas don't typically talk back, do they?
They're talking directly to us? Doesn't that scare you?

Fields.DialogueText: Anything they can say, we can say louder... and with better aim!
Depends on the Morgana, I think. But they all burn the same!
If it's a conversation she wants, I'll give her one!
According to Command, the Morganas aren't just shooting at us. They're watching... and learning.
Maybe, but Belles learn quicker!
@BATTLE
How's the writing coming?
Slow. I'm having trouble coming up with a bad guy.
Maybe I can help. Who's your hero?
Well, the thing is... I'm not really sure I have one of those yet, either.
Got a plot?
Define "plot."

Fields.MenuText: How long have you been stuck like this? Have you even started?
Sounds like an... experimental story.
You haven't been inspired lately?

Fields.DialogueText: I started ages ago! But I'm still stuck on what to do. I feel like I've used all my good ideas already!
Oh, yeah, that's exactly what I'm doing. I know - I can make it about the weather and not need any characters at all!
You'd think being at sea and fighting all the time would get my creativity going, but... nothing!
There's got to be something that's caught your eye recently. What about those notes you were taking?
I know, I know. The real world is cool and all, but... maybe I'm just reading too much science fiction. Everything I write seems to have been done.
Have you tried reading another genre? A few crew members have some Westerns you might be interested in.
Eh, too low-tech.
Romances?
Too mushy.
Cookbooks?
... You know, you might be on to something.
Really? I was just joking.
No, I think I figured it out! Thanks, Cap!
... Any time?
Come on, let's blow up a Morgana to celebrate!
@BATTLE
Okay, remember what you said about Morganas learning?
I was going to talk to you about that. Were you aware -
And cookbooks! Captain, I promise these things are related! Now, what is cooking, when you get right down to it?
Following directions, didn't you say?
Exactly! Now, hear me out: I think war is like a big old cook off.

Fields.MenuText: ... You lost me.
If you can't take the heat, stay out of the battlefield?
Lexington, I don't think you've been getting enough sleep.

Fields.DialogueText: I thought I might, but that's part of the plan!
You're on the right track!
Really? I'm thinking I could keep this plan up for days!
Anyway, think of all the countries like chefs. Everyone's got a recipe in this contest, right? That's your war strategy.
I suppose.
And your logistics, your deployment, your tactics - those are the instructions. And to make it all work you have your soldiers and officers -
Ingredients.
Yeah, exactly! But wait! Maybe the judges are real connoisseurs. Maybe they've tasted everything, and the more they know, the less impressed they'll be. Those are the Morganas!
So you change the recipe on them.
Bingo! We Belles are like sugar and spice and everything nice - bringing out flavors and changing up the taste. But if you really want to innovate, you gotta do it every step of the way!
Okay, now you're just quoting your cookbook. What's your plan?
Don't ask me, Cap. Ask the crew! They're the ones who'll really make our war the prize chili we wanna whip up. The Morganas won't know what hit ‘em till they swallow!
Looks like we've got Morganas. Maybe your metaphors will confuse them into surrendering.
Just the way my mind works, Captain. But you know, never say never...
@BATTLE
Okay, you've had some time to lay it all out for the crew. What exactly are you trying to do here?
I'm glad you asked, Cap! Watch and learn - I'm about to give those Morganas a taste of some soul food!
Why... why am I seeing pink? Is that a pink smokescreen?
Let's see how the Morganas deal with this!
@BATTLE
That was one confused Morgana, if I ever saw one!
I'd certainly be confused if my enemies blinded me with pink... stuff.
Had some pink sugar lying around, Captain! You can't really see it in food, so why not throw it in some enemy faces?
How'd you get the crew to agree to this?
One of the fighter pilots came up with it! Kristoff's a pretty good cook, too.

Fields.MenuText: Can we really afford to use food as a weapon?
It's unconventional, but it worked. Maybe there's something to your cookoff analogy.
But why pink?

Fields.DialogueText: Probably not all the time, but we'll come up with other ideas...
Just wait till you see what we cook up next!
Why not?
What's with this shipment of ink ribbons, Lexington?
A year's supply, Captain! If my math is right, I should burn through it in... two months? Give or take a day, assuming I keep my current pace...
I haven't seen you this inspired in a while. Is it something you can tell me about?
It's a mystery.
You don't know whether you can tell me?
No, silly, it's a mystery story! Listen, you remember that whole cooking thing? Recipes and ingredients and all that jazz?
What's the connection?
It's a cook off again, Captain! Except the grand prize is some missing treasure, and all the cooks are coming at it with different recipes. Investigations. Whatever.
I don't pretend to understand your creative process, but it seems to be working.
Like a charm. I'm up to three thousand words a day!

Fields.MenuText: So when do we get to read it?
It's starting to sound more like a novel than a short story.
Just remember that those Morganas won't wait for you to finish a chapter.

Fields.DialogueText: When it's done. You can't rush quality. Except in the skunk works...
Yeah, I think I'll skip the contest. For now, I should compare myself to myself, you get me?
So... either I shoot faster or write faster. Got it!
@BATTLE
Captain, Morganas on our six!
What!? Where did they come from? And is that a smokescreen?
No time to worry about it! Let's scramble and start shooting!
@BATTLE
Ugh... what a melee that was. Visibility's never been worse.
You're telling me, Captain. I didn't think Calamity would use all that smoke.
I'm not used to Morganas using that tactic. Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
I think word's getting around about us. Isn't it cool?

Fields.MenuText: That's not the word I'd use. They're adapting, and they're doing it faster and faster.
It's certainly interesting from a scientific perspective, but dangerous from a military one.
Lexington, this is a matter of life and death! We're lucky your pilots got out all right.

Fields.DialogueText: But don't you see? If they just copy us, we can predict their strategy and fight back even easier!
That's what makes it interesting!
Luck's got nothing to do with it. They're all trained to deal with that kind of thing. Gotta learn on your feet out here!
Well, we'd better keep innovating. You've turned this war into an arms race.
Every war is like that, Captain. Remember the Civil War?
No.
Whoops, I guess you wouldn't. But you know how the South fought back against the Union blockade.
Ironclads.
Ironclads! My great-granddaddies. But then the North got their own, so the South built a submarine, and on and on and on.
And now here we are with aircraft carriers.
Sooner or later, you're going to run into a better boat. We'll just have to keep sinking ‘em and never stop moving forward.
All ahead full, Lexington! They're disrupting our communications!
I'll disrupt their faces!
@BATTLE
That'll teach ‘em to go near our mail!
We can only hope. You weren't expecting anything, were you?
... Oh, crackers, you're right! I was waiting on an answer from Saratoga! It should have come in with that shipment.
The one the Morganas blew up.
Well, ain't that just peachy. I'll have to rewrite it, with updates. The last one would barely fit in an envelope. I'll need a folder...

Fields.MenuText: What do sisters write to each other about, exactly?
You might send Saratoga a draft of your work while you're at it.
Is Saratoga as much of a writer as you are?

Fields.DialogueText: Everything humans write about, of course! What we're doing, how we're feeling, how the new guns are holding up... okay, maybe not everything humans write about.
I can't do that! She wouldn't understand it. Besides, I never show my stories unless I'm positive they're ready.
No, I'm the writer in the family. She's actually a huge film nut! Ever since they filmed Hell Divers aboard her back in ‘32... don't get her started, Captain!
I'll see that you get in contact with her as quickly as possible. Keeping the lines of communication clear is one of the most important parts of the war effort.
Amen to that!
Lexington, what were the pilots grinning about?
Watch and learn, Captain. One of the bomber pilots had a really keen idea...
A safe idea?
If we wanted safe, we'd stick to the coasts!
@BATTLE
Good work out there. I'd almost call that brutal.
I can't take any of the credit. Did you see my pilots out there? It was a circus!
Just what were your pilots saying to the Morganas as they flew by?
Oh, just your typical schoolyard insults. Questioning the intelligence of their mothers, that sort of thing.
I don't see why you thought that would be helpful.
I figure it's important to throw as many new things at the Morganas as possible. If we keep them confused, we stand a better chance of them making a critical error.

Fields.MenuText: You're taking your experiments too far. I don't like you making a game out of a life-or-death situation.
Why didn't the Morgana just ignore the pilots?
That's either the cleverest or the riskiest approach to disorienting an opponent I've ever heard of. Well done.

Fields.DialogueText: Take it up with the pilots, Captain. They're just doing what works for them, and if it works for them,  it works for me.
They probably tried. But when you have that many pilots all screaming your direction, well... easier said than done.
No reason it can't be both!
I suppose if it works, it works. All the better to keep the enemy off guard.
Anyway, I was thinking we get the rest of the fleet to play, and then -
That's going to have to be Command's call.
Lexington, what's wrong?
Oh... nothing, Captain.
Okay, then, if you're sure...
Whoops, looks like this ink ribbon's dry.
*BOOM*
What the - If it's dry, throw it away, don't shoot it!
I'm outside for a reason.
Okay, tell me the truth. What's got you in this mood?
Mail's back up.
Really? I thought Command weren't sending us any more until they could secure another transport.
It came by air. Take a look.
"... though we appreciate your contribution, we cannot at this time..." A rejection letter?
I sent some of my new Isaac Davis story to that one publishing house. It's a form letter, Captain. They didn't even put my name on it!

Fields.MenuText: It's not your name.
That's disappointing. Did they say why?
That's no excuse to be throwing a fit.

Fields.DialogueText: You know what I mean, Captain. I'm still not ready to go public with it.
No! They just said it wasn't "what they were looking for." What does that even mean?
No, you're right. I shouldn't have shot the ink ribbon.
I just... it's a little like I've hit a wall.
So hit it again.
What?
You're the irrepressible Lady Lex. If you hit a wall, you find a way around it, over it, or through it. Don't you have a supersonic spud gun for that sort of thing?
It exploded. I screwed up the pressure on my latest model.
Even so -
I know what you mean, though... so, thanks. Just gotta hit the typewriter again...
As long as you don't shoot it.
@BATTLE
Mail's here!
Really? I didn't hear it arrive.
I just picked it up from where it usually is. Didn't see the pilot this time either. Let's see... crew, crew, magazine, crew... wait.
Something wrong?
It's... Saratoga?
I was wondering when we'd hear from her again.
But this can't be right... it's just a postcard. We practically write each other novels...
What's it say? Maybe she was just busy?
Lexington?
Never you mind, Captain. I was just thinking I wasn't angry enough for the Morganas today.
@BATTLE
You've been awfully quiet lately.
I've been busy.
Well, let me know if you need anything.
How do you spell "treacherous?"
All right, what's going on?
You think you know someone, and then...
You've still got that postcard from Saratoga?
Feel free to read it.
She's... saying goodbye?
She's cutting off contact.
What? Why would she do that?
Who knows? Keep reading.
"... and as for Aunt Langley, she's still asleep. She'll stay that way, and maybe she'd rather." Lexington, this can't be Saratoga.
Then what's her signature doing down there? The only people who see it are her and me.

Fields.MenuText: This has to be some kind of trick. We'll get to the bottom of this.
I just can't believe that Saratoga would suddenly start acting so cold.
Sulking won't help. We can't let family disputes get in the way of our mission.

Fields.DialogueText: It's just got to be. Think, Lexington... how would you write this?
Neither can I, but there's no way it could have been forged... right?
Belles are supposed to be close to their sisters. That's just how we're built.
You said you didn't see the pilot?
Not these last couple of times.
Try to get a good look at the plane next time. Something isn't right...
I'll say. There's a Morgana over there trying to be uglier than Saratoga.
You don't know for sure that she wrote this. That's a little harsh.
She probably did something to earn it. Sisters are like that.
@BATTLE
Captain, we've got to get away from here, now!
Slow down, Lexington. What's this all about?
You haven't seen the mail yet? I'm sure glad I got to it first!
Just tell me what's going on!
Command! They're recalling you and having me decommissioned!
What!? Give that to me, right now!
What are we going to do, Captain? I can't fight my sisters! What did we even do?
Stop. Just stop. Look at this.
What? I read it something like twelve -
Look here. See what happens when I hold it up to a light?
What do you mean?
Command's official communications have a watermark of their insignia. There's no watermark.
So... no decommissioning?
Barring high treason, no.
Oh, man... Captain, does this mean that the Saratoga letter is bogus too?
It might. Who's been bringing this mail?
It's been coming by air. I was there to greet the pilot, but his face was hidden. Weird...
Like following directions... Lexington, I think we know who's behind this.
Morganas.
We'll worry about the how later. Let's focus on the who.
And speak of the devil... action stations!
@BATTLE
Do we have any more coffee?
I'm sure we do. You're still working?
I have to. It's been too long since I hit my daily quota.
Just don't overwork yourself. There's a war on.
You remember Amelia Earhart, Captain?
How could I forget? First woman to fly across the Atlantic...
I must have read her memoir six times. I've just been thinking about her lately. I helped look for her, you know.

Fields.MenuText: If only you'd found her.
Really? I don't remember hearing about that.
What ended up happening to her?

Fields.DialogueText: You try searching the Pacific for a single plane.
Oh, yeah! Me and Itasca and Colorado, a couple Japanese ships... at least we tried.
She could have gone back to New Britain, crashed on Howland Island... hell, she might have just run out of gas. Nobody knows. Maybe nobody ever will.
It makes you think, doesn't it? If someone had some way to keep in contact, maybe she'd still be alive. So I don't like to use the same tactics, Captain... I'd get caught off guard.
Like you were when the Morganas learned to write.
It had to have been that mail ship, Captain. I was thinking about it while I was writing my mystery story. They destroyed it, they... assimilated it... they learned from it.
Assimilated it?
You must have seen it. Those Morganas are scavengers. I recognized some American flags and guns from a couple of them. Letters and handwriting would be cake for them.
Good thing blasting them is cake for you.
I could really go for some right about now...
@BATTLE
Leave this to me, Captain! It's time to end this!
Watch yourself, Lexington! They could be baiting us.
Let 'em! They're gonna catch a shark on a fishing pole!
@BATTLE
Ugh... what a mess.
Everything okay?
Fine. We might need to rotate the radio crew a little quicker for a while.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you'd solved the morale problem.
I'll put in a request to Command for more operators.
Sounds like that Morganas have started giving as good as they're getting.

Fields.DialogueText: At first, but you know what we're up against. We might have to try something new.
That might work, but I want to ask our crew what they think.
I had to talk one of our operators out of their quarters after the battle. They heard... well, I won't go into it.
This is madness. I don't know how you Belles handle it.
Handle what?
All the tricks the Morganas have up their sleeves. You saw how they targeted you. That Saratoga letter... the decommissioning order...
It's rough out here. Sometimes even I get worried. But you know what I say to that, Captain?
What?
To hell with worrying. That's like admitting you don't know the answer but not bothering to find the truth. What's the worst that could happen?
I want to like your attitude. But if the Morganas can scare you, what chance do humans have?
All the chances in the world! Fear's just like a vegetable. We all have to eat it sometimes. Just gotta find a good palate cleanser.
You're slipping into cooking metaphors again.
Can't help it, Cap! Success makes me hungry.
Got any desk space?
Sure, let me move my -
Great, thanks!
You finished your book? Congratulations... um, how many pages is that?
Enough.
Which is...
Just read it and find out!

Fields.MenuText: Lexington, it'll have to wait until the next port. I can't pick up a book in the middle of a warzone.
Well, all right, but I won't go easy on you just because you're my ship.
I'll try and flip through it.

Fields.DialogueText: No excuses, Captain. I can write one!
Go as hard as you want, Captain. I can take it!
Nope! No skimming. You don't have to like it, but you're gonna read this thing cover to cover!
What kind of mystery did you come up with?
I thought a lot about this, Cap. Why is it that we don't know things?
I suppose because we can't be there to see everything. So we guess, or we rely on those who saw what happened.
Or who say they saw what happened. But what if nobody knew? That's what I'm cooking with. Think a whole boatload of chefs who have to figure out a recipe by taste.
That reminds me, when are you cooking again?
Once you return my manuscript, with annotations!
Big incentive.
The biggest! And speaking of the biggest... hey, Morganas! You're blocking the horizon!
@BATTLE
Mail's here.
You sure?
Lexington, I checked. It came on one of Command's transports, sealed and untampered with. I assume this package is yours.
Ooh! Give it here!
Another manuscript?
A letter from Saratoga! Finally, I've been waiting forever...
You two must have a lot to say to each other.
We just lead exciting lives!
... Lexington, is everything okay?
... Better than okay, Captain. Look!
"... and although Aunt Langley still hasn't woken up, I definitely think she talks in her sleep..." What's that mean?
It's a Belle thing! Remember how we carriers can talk to our aircraft, even if they don't really talk back like we do?
Sure.
I don't know how to explain it, but Saratoga felt... something from Langley. A sound, a vision - hell, even just a tingle in your engines! She's in there somewhere, we know it!
You mean she's waking up?
Maybe not now, but someday, Captain, someday!

Fields.MenuText: Planning a family reunion?
You'd better stay afloat, then.
I don't know... Belles are one thing, but this just seems like magic.

Fields.DialogueText: You betcha! Those Morganas better start running scared...
Easier done than said!
If I can get my family back, I don't care what it is!
Let me know what else Saratoga says. I'd love to meet your... aunt.
I bet she'd love to meet you! And some help against these Morganas wouldn't hurt... not that we need it, right, Cap?
Looks ugly out there today. We'll take what we can get.
@BATTLE
Building a bigger potato gun?
No, but you got the right idea!
What, did you need to shoot a bigger ink ribbon?
Ha! Nope, I'm done being frustrated. Check this out!
What am I looking at?
I got the idea from this space battle I read in Amazing Stories. Ever heard of a railgun?
Never.
Well, forget supersonic potato guns. This baby can shoot a one-pound shell at six times the speed of sound!
You're joking.
It'd be super funny if I were! See, you've got these two rails here - hence the name - and once you get a current going, it's basically an electromagnet that shoots -
Let's pretend for a moment that I'm not a mechanic.
Oh, fine! Basically, if I hook this up to my generators, we'll be able to snipe those Morganas from fifty miles away!
Now that's just science fiction. You'd have to have enough electricity to -
To power a whole city?
... Probably. Why?
Tacoma, Washington. Winter of 1929. The dam was down, so they hooked me up to the power grid for a month. I still get fan mail.
I guess I underestimated you.
Life's all about surprises, Cap! Especially the ones you make up.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
